1063046837379219457.text: You could also consider transforming this average absolute deviation from the goal price value to a 0-1 scale to create a kind of a stable coin score and calculate it for different time-frames.

1063046250839359488.text: An example for this: if a stable coin has the value of 0.8 usd constantly, for a long time, it can have a 0 standard deviation value, even though it does a very bad job as a stable coin since it should be 1 usd.

1063045670557360128.text: I see that you already display a standard deviation value, which is similar, but the problem with it is that it is based on a mean value, not the goal price. So it is a good indicator of stability, but not great for stability around a fixed price.

1063045152057552897.text:
This could practically be a modified version of this: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_absolute_deviation …
Where the center is always the target price, not a mean value.
Alternatively it could be a percentage of deviation, I'm not convinced yet, which one is better.

1051441473319854080.text: I actually made an argument why the naming was unfortunate in one of our training modules at @HelloSolidityhttps://twitter.com/VitalikButerin/status/1051160932699770882 …
